FacilityName: Farmers Union Oil Company, Montevideo NH3 Plant

_emerg_resp.FR_OtherRegulation: ANSI Standards 2014 edition to include customer & fire department training

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Farmers Union Oil Company                                                                                  Montevideo, MN, Chippewa



EXECUTIVE SUMMARY - AMMONIA(anhydrous)



This facility complies with the 1989 ANSI K61.1 "Safety Requirement for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia".  In addition, it is our policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local laws.



One of our company Goals states, "To provide for the Safety and Security of our employees, our customers, the general public and to be good stewards of the environment for which we serve."  To fulfill these goals, we enroll in regulatory management service that assists in maintaining and administer comprehensive safety and environment programs, procedures and training courses.  We perform a thorough annual audit program and monitor facility compliance with the safety standards and overseen assistance with this specialty firm.  The program consists of internal audit utilizing checklists survey forms that are reviewed regularly and updated as necessary to ensure all applicable federal, state, and local regulations are covered.  These checklists are used to measure regulatory compliance including those governing the safe handling and storage of anhydrous.  Procedures require a timely response and correction of all recommendations resulting from these audit checklists.



A 'Site Safety Coordinator' is identified and used as an extension of the general manager and management service personnel for a "hands on" manager of the day to day safe working activities, maintain the required regulatory recordkeeping, conduct monthly safety meetings, conduct employee training and act as the location's contact during emergency incidents that are rehearsed biannually.  



A DESCRIPTION OF THE FACILTY AND THE REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED



The facility is a wholesale farm supply and distribution center and as such we store and distribute a wide variety of pesticides and fertilizers including anhydro

us ammonia.  Anhydrous Ammonia is received by (truck and/or rail), is handled and stored on-site and is a regulated substance by the EPA requiring us to comply with this Risk Management Program.  We sell anhydrous ammonia to growers in nurse tanks manufactured to the requirements to do such.  The customer applies the ammonia in the soil as a needed source of nitrogen fertilizer for growing agricultural crops.  Ammonia is also used for blending into mixed grade liquid fertilizers for crop production nutrients.



Our facility maintains 27 1,000-gallon nurse tanks and/or 17 1,500-gallon tanks nurse tanks for customer delivery.  Our combined storage capacity in nurse tanks is 44,000 gallons.  Anhydrous ammonia is stored in 3 stationary storage tanks; two @ 30,000 gallons and one @ 18,000 gallons)

340,782 pounds of anhydrous ammonia is the maximum storage capacity of the stationary storage tanks.  Therefore, the total facility anhydrous ammonia storage capacity for this location is 570,155 pounds.  The largest storage vessel at our facility contains 131,070 pounds.



WORST CASE SCENARIO



Our worst case scenario is the loss of the total contents of the 30,000 gallon storage tank, when filled to the greatest amount allowed (85% of capacity), released as a liquid over 10 minutes, resulting total vaporization.  The maximum quantity released would be 30,000 x 85% x 5.14 pounds.  According to DEGRADIS modeling, the distance to the endpoint (point of dispersion to 200 PPM) would have off-site impact.  It should be noted that our company has never had a total release of an entire storage tank.



ALTERNATE RELEASE SCENARIO



The most common alternate release scenario(s) from an anhydrous ammonia storage facility would not reach an endpoint off-site.  The alternate release scenario modeled for the purpose of this plan is a two-minute release from a stationary storage tank representing a valve and hose failure requiring a manual shutdown.  The total amount of anhydrous ammon

ia released in this scenario would 300 pounds for a storage tank.  The distance to endpoint would not have an impact.



GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



The ammonia storage system is designed, installed and is maintained in accordance with ASTM standards and the ASME codes. This facility complies with the ANSI 

K61.1 standards (1999 edition), OSHA - 29 CFR 1910.111, EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule as well as all applicable federal, state, and local codes and regulations.



Our ammonia system is protected from major releases by internal excess flow valves, check valves, relief valves, manual shutoffs and emergency shutoff valves.  The load-out risers used for the purpose of filling the nurse tanks are protected by excess flow valves and fill lines breakaways to immediately stop the flow of ammonia if a line or a hose would fail.  All of the main storage tank valves and the riser load valves are locked when not in use.  Lighting for the facility has increase to discourage the increase of meth theft along with a barb-wire chain-link fence being proposed.



Our ammonia anhydrous system is inspected on a regular basis with maintenance and preventive maintenance scheduled and documented.  Liquid and vapor valves, hoses, excess flow valves, gauges, and relief valves are replaced when necessary and/or according to the guidelines within the ANSI standards.



Training is provided to all employees at least annually, whenever there is a change in the process or whenever competencies with the regulations are questioned.  In accordance with the 1989 ANSI standards, training is also offered for all ammonia customers to attend on a regular basis and offered to the local fire department personnel during their annual tour of our facility and operations.  These training courses consist of classroom lecture, current and approved videos or compact disc, testing both verbally and written, demonstration and observation f

or each person working the process that are certified while on-going job training is always improved upon.



FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



There has been no accidents involving anhydrous ammonia that has caused deaths, recordable injuries, property or environmental damage including evacuations on or off site.



The 'EMERGENCY RESPONSE AND CONTINGENCY PLAN'



In the event of an emergency involving our ammonia system, it is our policy to notify the local community fire department and request that they respond to the emergency with the facility's personnel assistance.  In preparation for this, we have coordinated with all of the local response agencies by providing information and facility tours annually to ensure that they are familiar with and properly prepared for an incident at our facility.  This will help to ensure that our community has the strategy for responding to and mitigating the threat posed by an ammonia release.  This complies with the requirement for our facility to be included in the community emergency response plan prepared under EPCRA and coordinated with our LEPC.
